data.title: Fix mouse wheel delta to be consistent with XNA
data.body:
A little context: I'm porting CraftStudio (http://craftstud.io/) to MonoGame to make it run on Linux and MacOS X. It's a game-making platform so it touches a lot of stuff.

The user interface mostly runs on MonoGame but scrolling with the mouse wheel doesn't work because mouse wheel delta values in XNA and MonoGame are inconsistent.

XNA returns mouse wheel deltas in 120 increments whereas in MonoGame.Framework/Desktop/Input/Mouse.cs, the ScrollWheelValue is set to OpenTK's mouse.Wheel which has been divided by 120 (see line 307 at http://www.opentk.com/files/doc/_win_g_l_native_8cs_source.html)

My fix switches to "(int)(mouse.PreciseWheel \* 120);" which basically undoes OpenTK's division to get the original value back, just as XNA uses it.

data.title: GraphicsDeviceManager merged into one single file.
Develop3d - Fix crash when calling Guide.BeginShowKeyboardInput on Galaxy S devices
data.body:
This exception may happen on lots of other devices too, but it does not happen on my Novo Tornado tablet. The exception "Java.Lang.RuntimeException: Can't create handler inside thread that has not called Looper.prepare()" was thrown when "new EditText(Game.Activity)" was called.

I fixed it by wrapping the whole AlertDialog creation in the Activity.RunOnUiThread invoker. I think it's probably better that it blocks the UI thread sooner rather than later anyway. Creating the AlertDialog can take a while on slower devices (> 1 sec), so blocking the UI thread may avoid users tapping stuff whilst the AlertDialog is being created. In the future we should consider whether the text entry AlertDialog should be pre-created and cached, or possibly just cached after the first creation.

Note that the changes appear more radical than they are due to some white space cleanup.

data.title: Default window title should use GetEntryAssembly, not GetCallingAssembly
data.body:
The default window title initialized in Game.cs doesn't match XNA's behavior when using a Game class inherited in another assembly.

Context: I'm using my own library NuclearWinter which inherits Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Game as NuclearGame. When I instantiate a NuclearGame, the resulting window in MonoGame is titled "NuclearWinter" instead of "My Game's Name".

MonoGame's Game.cs uses GetCallingAssembly() which returns "NuclearWinter" instead of the actual game's name. GetEntryAssembly() seems to return the actual game's assembly.

As such, replacing:

```
        var assembly = Assembly.GetCallingAssembly();
```

by:

```
        var assembly = Assembly.GetEntryAssembly();
```

fixes the bug.

I could have submitted a patch but I figured it wasn't worth it for this one-liner.

data.title: Develop3d - Android: Fix dynamic orientation and merge in lock screen changes from develop branch
data.body:
Initially I intended to just make the Orientation sample function as it does in develop branch, however this was harder than expected and I ended up reworking the way orientation changes are handled. I also included Dean's recent ScreenReceiver and associated changes from develop branch. 

Notes:
- GraphicsDeviceManager.ApplyChanges() can now do stuff. In particular it updates presentation parameters and triggers orientation changes if the current orientation becomes unsupported.
- GraphicsDeviceManager.ResetClientBounds() has been taken from develop and modified. It correctly updates the Viewport now. It attempts to ensure you are always working with the preferred aspect ratio, but it does not modify the buffer size. It's debatable how useful preserving the aspect ratio across orientation changes is. Particularly so when the aspect ratio is implied by the preferred buffer W & H and some devices with only soft keys on the task bar change aspect on orientation change.
- AndroidGameWindow now implements ISurfaceHolderCallback.SurfaceChanged as a means of delaying the response to orientation change until it's fully propogated.
- Cleaned up some code in Game.cs. I know some of this not Android specific, but I believe non-Android actual functionality is not affected (remember ResetClientBounds() used to be empty on develop3d).
